query: Surrealist Memes: Regression or Progression?

summary.claim: Surrealist memes can be a driving force in the progression of meme art

perspectives.text: Surrealist memes find cultural forbears in the pre-internet art movements of Dadaism, Surrealism and Pop Art.
This ongoing dialogue between various art movements and surreal memes points to the latter’s power as a driving force in the progression of meme art.

By referencing Dali in the same image as Pepe the Frog, surreal memes accomplish another central goal of Pop Art – to mix high and low culture and elevate ordinary, daily items into the world of fine art.

summary.claim: Surrealist memes are devoid of any distinct message

perspectives.text: A central criticism of surreal memes is that they don’t have any point, that they are devoid of any distinct message.
To these critics, I (along with troves of surrealist memers) say, so what? Art needn’t have a particular message in order to qualify as art, or even to qualify as good art.
The most deadening influence on art in our time is the belief that content matters more than style.

query: Throwback TV: Friends or Seinfeld?

summary.claim: Friends is more influential than Seinfeld

perspectives.text: Friends set the bar and path for the creation of more successful sitcoms, and its focus on friendship has aged better than Seinfeld
Without Friends, there would be no How I Met Your Mother, New Girl, or The Big Bang Theory
Netflix paid $100M to stream the series for 12 months, citing that it was the second-most watched program among American viewers in 2018

summary.claim: Seinfeld is more influential than Friends

perspectives.text: Seinfeld revolutionized television with its story lines about everyday life, making a lasting impact on the industry
Seinfeld made taboo issues comic gold, turning them into a cultural hotbed for viewers to bond over
Seinfeld's rich catalogue of unique references has contributed to our modern-day vernacular

query: Should Gwyneth Paltrow be admired or criticized?

summary.claim: Gwyneth Paltrow should be admired for her ability to redefine modern family structures and her resilience in the face of sexual harassment.

perspectives.text: Paltrow showed the resilience by being one of the first actresses to come forward about having been sexually harassed by Harvey Weinstein.
Paltrow combatted a lull in her star power by launching a lifestyle blog, Goop, that revealed (albeit, selectively) her diet, exercise regimen, and parenting techniques.

Paltrow has become even more visible by taking on more diverse roles involving singing and dancing, such as a recurring role in the TV show Glee, a star turn in the blockbuster franchise Iron Man, and a central role in the TV show The Politician.

summary.claim: Gwyneth Paltrow should be criticized for her pretentious lifestyle brand, Goop, and her tendency to promote unproven health trends.

perspectives.text: Goop has marketed pseudo-scientific products and services like jade eggs, vaginal steaming and stickers that supposedly rebalance your energies.
Goop’s products are considered too expensive and lavish even for the average well-off reader.
Paltrow has promoted a macrobiotic diet, came out loudly as a raw foodist, and took a very long time to accept eating chicken.

query: The Perspective on Reality TV

summary.claim: Reality TV can broaden our horizons and humanize the unknown

perspectives.text: Reality TV shows how people react to different situations and as an audience get to see how it all pans out.
Queer Eye for the Straight Guy rescued clueless heteros and presented marginalized groups with relatable casts.
Lifetime’s Little Women respectfully approached the lives of women with dwarfism.

summary.claim: Reality TV can lead to the overexamination and downfall of its participants

perspectives.text: Reality TV stars prove that the overexamined life isn’t worth living.
Nick Lachey and Jessica Simpson of MTV’s Newlyweds divorced under the specter of reality TV fame.
Heidi Montag of the The Hills says her reality TV experience fueled her plastic surgery obsession.

query: Should we Fight or Embrace Illegal Downloads?

summary.claim: Affordable alternatives to illegal downloads exist

perspectives.text: There are too many cheap alternatives to illegal downloading to continue perpetuating the activity.
Netflix and Amazon Prime Video are less than $10 a month and give easy access to the most popular TV shows and movies.
Amazon Kindle books are usually less than $10, with a one-time purchase of a device that can support e-books.
Spotify grants access to millions of songs and podcasts for less than it costs to go out to dinner.

summary.claim: Fighting illegal downloads is necessary to protect the music industry

perspectives.text: File-sharers are directly responsible for damaging the music industry.
The decline in music revenues in the past 8 years can be fully attributed to illegal file sharing.

query: How Should We View Michael Jackson’s legacy?

summary.claim: Michael Jackson’s legacy should be viewed in a positive light due to his contributions to music, charity, and sports

perspectives.text: He revolutionized music videos and live performance.
He gave millions in charity and was one of the first celebrities to establish his own charitable foundation.
He helped his players grow in ways that others couldn’t, teaching big egos to be more team-oriented.
He pioneered a new era in music video, enchanting audiences with the Moonwalk, not to mention cinematic and special effects marvels like Thriller, Black or White, and Scream.
He used his star power to rally other performers to charity anthems like Heal the World and We Are the World, an iconic song emphasizing humanity that he co-wrote with Lionel Richie.
He popularized an ethos of harmony and shared responsibility through songs like Man in the Mirror and They Don’t Really Care About Us.

summary.claim: Michael Jackson’s legacy should be viewed in a negative light due to his controversies and allegations of child abuse

perspectives.text: He was accused of child molestation and was acquitted in 2003, but the allegations continue to follow him.
He was known for his bizarre behavior, including having two spur-of-the-moment marriages and frequent changes in his appearance.
He tried to create marketing stunts, such as seeking knighthood from the late Queen of England, to deflect bad press.
A former Jackson publicist alleged that Jackson leaked rumors about himself and behaved strangely to build celebrity through spectacle.
The allegations of child abuse against him have had a lasting impact on his legacy.
The documentary Leaving Neverland has further tarnished his reputation.
He was accused of using his fame and wealth to exploit and abuse those around him.
His family members were also accused of taking advantage of him and his assets.
He was known for his eccentric behavior, which was often seen as a way to build his celebrity.
The allegations of child abuse against him are a stain on his legacy.
He was accused of using his fame and wealth to exploit and abuse those around him.

perspectives.text: There is enough space on the door for Jack to be saved.
Improving the buoyancy of the raft could have made it possible to save Jack.
Jack would have sacrificed himself to save Rose.

summary.claim: Jack could not have been saved

perspectives.text: The script states that Jack should give his place to Rose.
The door would not have been buoyant enough to support both Jack and Rose.

query: Which is better: Star Wars Vs. Star Trek?

summary.claim: Star Wars is better than Star Trek

perspectives.text: Star Wars has a more iconic and beloved characters, such as Han Solo and Luke Skywalker, that have become part of popular culture.
Star Wars has a more visually stunning and epic space battles, which have been widely imitated in other science fiction films.
Star Wars has a more engaging and complex storyline, with a richly detailed universe and a strong focus on character development.

summary.claim: Star Trek is better than Star Wars

perspectives.text: Star Trek has a more optimistic and hopeful vision of the future, with a focus on exploration and cooperation rather than conflict and competition.
Star Trek has a more intellectually stimulating and thought-provoking storyline, with a focus on science and technology rather than action and adventure.
Star Trek has a more diverse and inclusive cast of characters, with a focus on representation and social justice.

query: Is Binge-Watching a harmless or helpful activity?

summary.claim: Binge-watching can be a harmless and enjoyable activity

perspectives.text: Binge-watching can provide a sense of escapism and allow viewers to enjoy complex fiction without waiting for each episode to be released.
Binge-watching can be a way to relax and unwind after a long day.

summary.claim: Binge-watching can have negative effects on physical and mental health

perspectives.text: Binge-watching can lead to poor sleep quality, fatigue, and increased risk of depression and sedentary habits.
Binge-watching can contribute to an early death due to prolonged sitting and decreased physical activity.

perspectives.text: She is a victim of the Joker's manipulation and abuse.
Her actions are driven by her desire to please the Joker and gain his love.
She has a strong sense of compassion and loyalty for the people in her life.

summary.claim: Harley Quinn is primarily a villain due to her involvement in violent crimes and her willingness to harm others.

perspectives.text: She has committed numerous violent crimes, including murder and assault.
Her actions are driven by her desire to prove herself to the Joker and gain his approval.
She has a history of manipulating and using people for her own gain.

query: Hamilton – overrated or worth the hype?

summary.claim: Hamilton is worth the hype

perspectives.text: Hamilton has been fortunate to receive unlimited accolades and great reviews, but let’s not forget the less heard voice. Not everyone wants to pay a fortune to see the musical and those who do are not always impressed with the score, scenery, or have patience to sit through a 2 hour and 45 minute history lesson.
Hamilton has been fortunate to receive unlimited accolades and great reviews, and its score and lyrics are fresh, innovative and catchy.

summary.claim: Hamilton is not worth the hype

perspectives.text: Hamilton has been fortunate to receive unlimited accolades and great reviews, but let’s not forget the less heard voice. Not everyone wants to pay a fortune to see the musical and those who do are not always impressed with the score, scenery, or have patience to sit through a 2 hour and 45 minute history lesson.
Hamilton has been overhyped, and its plot is not as original as people think.

query: Is Hollywood too white?

summary.claim: Hollywood is working to increase diversity in its casting and leadership

perspectives.text: Hollywood casting offices underrepresent people of color.
Most large studios and networks offer diversity programs and college internships to increase the share of positions given to screenwriters and directors of color.
The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences has made an effort to invite an increasing number of new members who are of varied nationality and color.
The Motion Picture Arts and Sciences invited 842 new members who hailed from 59 countries, and 29% were people of color.
The academy invited 395 new artists of whom 39% were underrepresented ethnic/racial communities, and 59% were international from 49 countries.

summary.claim: Hollywood is still predominantly white and does not adequately represent people of color

perspectives.text: Ninety-four percent of major production studio executives are white.
The composition of Hollywood’s executive offices and professional guilds is even less promising.
Only 2 out of 10 lead actors in films were people of color in 2017.
Only 2.2 out of 10 lead actors in broadcast scripted shows for TV were people of color.
The lack of diversity in Hollywood’s largest studios and broadcast networks has long been a point of contention.
Only 23% of films made from 2011 to 2015 featured a black lead.
In 2020, the number of black leads has risen to 39.7%, but it still shows disproportionate representation.
Even when a black star does score a lead role, it is most often against the backdrop of a white character who facilitates the black character’s success.

query: Game of Thrones: Epic or Epic Fail?

summary.claim: Game of Thrones can be epic and has a lot to offer

perspectives.text: Game of Thrones excels at being unpredictable, especially since its bold departure from the novels’ plotlines in season three. Alliances are constantly in shift, and major power players rise and fall through the course of a single episode.
Game of Thrones possesses a surprising amount of egalitarian themes, demonstrating the show’s lean toward gender equality.
Game of Thrones can’t make up its mind about what kind of show it wants to be.

summary.claim: Game of Thrones is often considered an epic fail

perspectives.text: The Game of Thrones series spends an inordinate amount of time developing pointless characters and half-cooked, directionless plotlines.
Heads are literally always rolling in Westeros, and seemingly, without much purpose other than challenging its audience to hold onto their dinners.

The show is rampant with sexual violence, sometimes inventing characters that never appeared in the books (like Ros, a prostitute whom Joffrey tortures to death) seemingly for the purpose of depicting sexual brutality.

query: Battle of the Bonds: Daniel Craig or Sean Connery?

summary.claim: Daniel Craig has financially rejuvenated the franchise

perspectives.text: Prior to Craig being cast, the James Bond franchise was suffering the effects of aging.
Craig’s Casino Royale debut was so acclaimed that the movie earned $599 million.
Craig’s third Bond film, Skyfall, which premiered in 2012, earned $1.1 billion.
Craig’s fourth Bond film, Spectre, premiered in 2015, and amassed $880 million worldwide.
Craig’s fifth and final Bond film, No Time to Die, raked in $708 million at the box office.

summary.claim: Sean Connery is the epitome of 007

perspectives.text: With his rugged good looks, charm and charisma, Connery set the sophisticated style of how Bond looked, dressed, wooed women, drank, used a gun and drove a car.
Connery’s mastery of witty dialogue has made his Bond the coolest and most collected of all.
Connery’s perfectly timed delivery of clever dialogue makes his Bond more amusing for viewers than his successors.
Connery brought unflappable calm to the role, whether he was killing bad people or charming women.

query: How great is ‘great literature’ if it needs to be studied to be understood?

summary.claim: Great Literature can enrich our lives and provide valuable life lessons

perspectives.text: Great Literature exposes students to a smorgasbord of emotions and literary devices. These devices, including time, space, allegory, etc., create a scene and a context. Mastering these devices may even help us live more ethical lives.
From studying literature, we learn about ourselves in greater perspective while learning to appreciate the many layers in art, and, indeed, life.
Great Literature asks its readers to locate its relevance and impact on society, both positive and negative.
Knowing how a story works provides us with tools that are relevant for many aspects of our practical lives.

summary.claim: Great Literature may be inaccessible to many people and can be alienating

perspectives.text: The study of Great Literature divides us into two camps: those who get it, and those who don't.
Take Ulysses. It’s supposed to be genius, but if readers can’t grasp it after hours of study, then they might think literature isn’t for them.
Literature is solitary and meant for intimate consumption, not class reading.
One person writes it, one person reads it.

query: Back to the Future: Musical or Movie. Which is better?

summary.claim: The musical is better than the movie

perspectives.text: The musical offers a more cynical look at the past and takes a more innovative approach to stagecraft.
The musical features a more diverse range of songs and a more dynamic performance.
The musical provides a more intimate and personal connection with the audience.

summary.claim: The movie is better than the musical

perspectives.text: The movie offers a richer and more action-packed story, with more Easter eggs and a more iconic score.
The movie provides a more immersive and engaging experience, with better special effects and a more convincing portrayal of the characters.
The movie is a more faithful adaptation of the original story, with a more nuanced and detailed exploration of the themes and characters.

query: Does Nicki Minaj Empower or Objectify women?

summary.claim: Nicki Minaj Empowers women

query: The Perspective on Time – Is It Linear or Cyclical?

summary.claim: Three Reasons Time is Linear
summary.perspective:
Here is the query and documents:
Query: The Perspective on Time – Is It Linear or Cyclical?
Documents:
[Doc 966]: All of our most common time measurement systems we use in daily life are cyclical: The repetition of 60 seconds into a minute, 60 minutes into an hour, 24 hours into a day, seven days into a week, (roughly) four weeks into a month, (roughly) three months into a season, and four seasons into a year. As such, don’t our feelings of déjà vu and the idea that history repeats itself support the notion that time is cyclical? If time were truly and naturally linear, wouldn’t we use linear, metric counting measures that proceed from a single starting point towards infinity, like distance measurements do?
[Doc 981]: Time is linear because of the different and cumulative ways we can record and measure it. Our Smartphone stopwatches measure time in milliseconds. This may be an absurd level of precision for daily life, but it is increasingly important as we push the limits of human athletic performance. We can also measure time by counting the number of times the Earth goes around the Sun, just as humans have done for thousands of years. If counted, this shows linear progress from a starting point onward. Or we can measure the vibration of cesium-133 atoms, as is done to set International Atomic Time. That global standard is so accurate that it will take 1.4 million years for it to be off by a full second. These natural phenomena can be recorded in long, cumulative and linear sequences.
[Doc 166]: Until recently, the lives of agricultural, nomadic, and even urban peoples were governed by the endlessly repeating seasonal round. Calendars, which portray time as a linear concept, are a recent phenomenon when compared to the long-term existence of our species. The earliest calendar may have developed as early as 10,000 years ago ; well-documented calendar systems don’t become common in the archaeological record until within the last 5,000 years. Our species is 200,000 years old; for at least 95% of humankind’s existence as a species, time was cyclical and circadian.
[Doc 993]: Have you noticed that our calendar years, i.e., linear timeframes, are counted as cumulative units from a particular starting point? This is because annual calendars are used by the political and religious powers to mark events they deem important, like the birth of Jesus, not natural or physical events or processes, like the origin of life on earth. What’s the difference between the Hebrew, Chinese, Gregorian, and Mayan calendars? Ultimately, and from the perspective of time itself, not much. These calendars have different origins, starting points, counting systems, and holidays that are relevant only to people, not animals, plants, or the planet. In the end, each of these calendars is nothing more than a cultural construct based on local political, religious, scientific, and economic systems created by humans.
[Doc 2202]: Frequently, a ban-whether or food, alcohol or forms of media- serves only to build interest in the things that has been prohibited. When a ban affects something that is a familiar part of everyday life that is generally regarded as benign, there is a risk that individuals may try to acquire the banned thing through other means. Having had their perspective in junk food defined partly by attractive, highly persuasive advertising, children are likely to adopt an ambivalent perspective on any attempt to restrict their dietary choices. The extreme contrast between the former popularity of vending machines in schools and the austere approach required by new policies may hamper schools’ attempts to convince pupils of the necessity and rationality of their decision. Even though schools may be able to coerce and compel their pupils to comply with disciplinary measures, they cannot stop children buying sweets outside of school hours. When rules at an Orange county school changed, and the cafeteria got rid of its sweets, the demand was still up high, so that the school had to figure out a way to fix the situation. They created a “candy cart” – which now brings them income for sports equipment or other necessities.

query: Can People Change Their Minds?

summary.claim: People can change their minds, and this change can be influenced by positivity and self-affirmation.

perspectives.text: Positivity can go a long way in changing people’s minds. According to the Washington Post, a review of Reddit’s ChangeMyMind forum revealed that people who remained polite and practiced hedging – a linguistic tool used to make an argument appear less threatening (“it may be that”) – succeeded more often in changing people’s minds.

Another study determined that people are more likely to change their minds when they feel good about themselves. People who had practiced positive self-affirmation before entering an argument were more influenced by the argument than those who had only argued, without the benefit of the self-affirmation activity.

summary.claim: There is no inherent limit to the ability of people to change their minds.

perspectives.text: The notion that people do not change their minds contradicts what we readily observe about the human experience. Many people who have eaten meat their whole lives have become vegetarians. People change religions or take one up after a lifetime of atheism. They change political parties, too; people tend to become more conservative with age.

This is not only in the same culture over hundreds of years, but also in several cultures that are very different to each other. Much of what is seen as faulty, or how people are treated when they show signs of faults, is different from culture to culture, but much is the same.

query: Should We Ban Unpaid Internships?

summary.claim: Three Reasons to Support Unpaid Internships
summary.perspective:
Please provide the JSON output for the given query and documents. 

```json
{
  "query": "Should We Ban Unpaid Internships?"
}
```


```json
[Doc 944]: As Prohibition demonstrated, if you ban something that people really want, they’ll still find a way to get it. If unpaid internships were banned, businesses would still get unpaid workers (especially in coveted or over-populated industries), in a way which may be unregulated and unsupervised. By maintaining a system of unpaid internships that is transparent, we can make sure that businesses don’t take advantage of interns or keep people trapped in unpaid jobs without any outside knowledge.
[Doc 1192]: If you support the idea of unpaid internships, it might be because you think they help people find jobs. But statistics by the National Association of Colleges (NACE) and Employers show that people who took unpaid internships were actually less likely to find a job than those who took paid internships. A student survey by NACE found that students completing an unpaid internship the year before graduation were more likely to be still seeking employment six months after receiving their degree than those who completed a paid internship. In addition, unpaid interns don’t seem to get any more job offers than their pals with intern experience at all.
[Doc 284]: Many people who support unpaid internships argue that businesses can’t afford to offer paid internships. However, unpaid internships may be bad for business. Unpaid interns tend to feel that their work is unimportant because they aren’t being paid for it, consequently leading some to expend only a meager effort. This doesn’t establish long-term loyalty. Businesses, then have to train someone with no loyalty to the company who could leave at any time. Meanwhile, paid interns feel more engaged with the company and more enthusiastic to give their all to the job.
[Doc 982]: The business world turns upon trust and relationships. Service providers often give a sample of their work for free. Likewise, product manufacturers provide free demos, and entrepreneurs understand that they need to spend money to prove that their concept works if they want to break into the market. Unpaid internships are no different than any of these examples. When young people work in unpaid internships, they are essentially building their CVs. By attaching their names to a reputable firm, that firm’s reputation stands out on the interns’ CVs. They are given the opportunity to demonstrate their dedication, work ethic and willingness to learn – not to mention acquire a wide range of skills and contacts – which are all vital for getting a good-paying job in the future. In fact, college students who had internships are 15% less likely to be unemployed in the years after graduating college than those who didn’t.
[Doc 2499]: Colleges offer career services, internships, job shadowing, job fairs, and volunteer opportunities in addition to a wide variety of courses that may provide a career direction. Over 80% of college students complete internships before graduation, giving them valuable employment experience before entering the job market.
[Doc 3289]: It's just not viable. If you ban something as sacred and religious as the veil, you're going to get people then issuing rallying cries for other things to be banned. At the end of the day if the Government feel that it is in the best interests not to ban the veil, then we have to believe them. If anything happen, it is the blood being spilt on their hands, but while this is not occurring, then there should be no reason to attempt to ban it.
[Doc 1781]: Aside from the fact that handguns are uniquely dangerous weapons, when the handgun ban was in place in DC, there was a reported decrease in crime in the area. In 1977 the year immediately following the ban the U.S. Conference of Mayors reported robberies, assaults and homicides using handguns had fallen in DC sharply. Further, in 1991 the University of Maryland published a study in the New England journal of Medicine suggesting the gun ban had saved lives in the decade before 1991, claiming that the ban had prevented 47 deaths

In fact, college students who had internships are 15% less likely to be unemployed in the years after graduating college than those who didn’t.

query: Is Honesty the Best Policy?

summary.claim: Honesty is the best policy because it builds trust and prevents harm to individuals and society.

perspectives.text: Society is built on trust. We go to stores expecting clerks to give us the true prices of merchandise. We believe food is okay to eat when there’s an expiration date listed by a reliable company. Trustworthy communities allow people to work together, communicate effectively and openly engage with “the other.”

The Flint water crisis in Michigan in 2014 is a prime example of the devastating consequences of dishonesty. Thousands of people were lied to about the unhealthy, lead-ridden state of their water, and many got sick as a result.
Lying kills relationships, where honesty protects integrity.

summary.claim: Honesty may not always be the best policy because it can be hurtful and damaging to relationships.

perspectives.text: Honesty can wound the people closest to us; sometimes, it doubles as a subtle form of assault, by allowing us to unload our angry feelings onto our loved ones through lashing out with true – yet brutal – criticism.
The white lie – a small lie told to avoid hurting a person’s feelings – originated somewhere, and for good reason: Not everyone is prepared to hear the truth.
Sometimes, honesty may harm our relationships more than it will benefit them.

query: Can the Use of Torture Be Justified?

summary.claim: Torture is abominable, no matter the circumstances
summary.perspective:
Note: I'll simulate the document IDs as doc_1, doc_2, etc. for simplicity. 

Here are the documents:

Doc 1765: The advantage of a complete ban on torture is that it leaves no room for doubt, no possibility for confusion, no need to apply personal judgement. Under the status quo, it is simply illegal to use force or the threat of force to solicit information from a suspect, regardless of the charge. The moment that becomes something other than a complete ban then it puts an intolerable pressure on security officials to decide when it is justified and when it is not. The experience of Abu Grahib demonstrates how the use of abusive treatment can become routine, even trivial, all too quickly. If it is acceptable to use torture to prevent mass-murder, then why not murder? If for murder than why not rape?
Doc 617: When respectable law enforcement institutions use torture, they risk damaging their hard-earned reputations and moral upstanding. The use of torture is a rejection of a democracy’s loyalty to abiding by societal rules and values. For example, torture directly contradicts the legal right to remain silent, which suspects are afforded when questioned. Citizens in Western countries trust that they’re living in a society where fair treatment and basic respect for human rights are a given. Therefore, when these ideals are compromised by organized government, the “good guys” sink to the level of those who threaten the very principles they are fighting to protect.
Doc 264: Torture is acceptable if it can save the lives of fellow citizens in “ ticking-bomb ” scenarios. Whether it’s an issue of national security or the potential death of kidnapped babies and toddlers, torture might be the only means of eliciting crucial information fast enough to rescue the people at risk. Although torture may not be legal, 60-70% of Americans think that torturing suspected terrorists can be a justifiable way of extracting information from them. Imagine if someone with information on the 9/11 attacks were to be captured, and torturing information out of him would have saved the lives of every Twin Tower victim; should his captors refrain from torturing him? The answer seems like a no-brainer.
Doc 535: When facing enemies that don’t subscribe to the rules of democracy and Western morals, governments may have to speak the language of their opponents to get results. Terrorist organizations like Al Qaeda don’t think twice about torturing their captives, and even have a manual to show members exactly what to do. During the Vietnam war, the North Vietnamese government re-purposed the Hoa Lo Prison in order to torture American POWs for information. If suspects (terrorists or otherwise) pose a threat to a nation and play by a different set of rules – rules that include the use of torture – the opposing government may have no choice but to do so as well. In fact, in some cases, torture may even be a deterrent to war, thus saving lives.
Doc 383: In times of war, armies may do whatever is necessary in order to save their country. By the very act of enlisting in military combat, a soldier has agreed to put his life on the line and die for his people if that’s what’s required of him — and suffering from torture can be a facet of that. Basic military training alone, specifically in elite units, can often involve some form of psychological or physical torture by the hands of a soldier’s own army to help strengthen soldiers’ immunity for worst-case scenarios. Such prisoner-of-war training exercises are par for the course when countries are preparing for war. During actual war, all bets are off, and torture is often an unavoidable consequence.

query: Should Prostitution be legalized?

summary.claim: Keep it criminal
summary.perspective:
Here is the query and documents for summarization:
Query: Should Prostitution be legalized?
Documents:
[Doc 3583]: As we’ve mentioned in our previous point, prostitution will take place whether it is legal or not. We believe prostitution should be legal. By regulating brothels and the conditions for prostitution through regular health checks, condoms et cetera, we can make sure prostitutes are safe from HIV. In places where prostitution is illegal, it is merely driven underground; controlled by cartels and gangs. In this situation prostitutes live under no rights. If a sex worker contracts AIDS, a man or woman client using them will be at risk of contracting the virus, they then run the risk of not knowing that they have it, infecting other sexual partners and the cycle continues. Also let us not forget future children who contract the disease while in the uterus. So it is in countries where prostitution is illegal where we can’t keep sex workers safe from AIDS. In these countries prostitutes aren’t even allowed to be prostitutes. They tend to enter the profession because they have no other way of earning money or they may be forced to do it. On the other hand, if prostitution is legal and regulations are put in place, sex workers will be safer from STI’s and HIV/AIDS. Regular health checks will pick up any possible infections and there will be laws to protect the well-being of sex workers. What’s more, these laws will not only protect sex workers, but their clients too. Making prostitution legal will improve the work conditions of people who have to go into prostitution for one reason or another and will protect society from a further spreading of HIV/AIDS. This is a significant benefit to greater society and individual workers and clients.
[Doc 3585]: The problem with the opposition proposal is that it is not mutually exclusive to legalising prostitution. It is perfectly possible for a Government to provide an education program and legalise prostitution at the same time, in fact that is what is done in places like New Zealand where prostitution is legal and we provide sex education in schools. In fact, legalising prostitution actually helps a wider education program. If the opp wants people to be properly educated about AIDS, then they should not want to exclude and stigmatise sex workers. If you continue to ban prostitution, then it actually entrenches the idea that prostitutes are somehow lesser people whose welfare we shouldn’t care about when it comes to HIV. As it is, countries that ban prostitution make no effort to protect prostitutes at all. To have a free and open discussion, it is necessary to allow a free discussion about prostitution, which can only happen if it is legal. If it is not, it is much more difficult to acquire information about prostitutes and about the conditions in which they work, because they are less willing to come forward and admit to what they are doing. The opp has conceded that there is a problem of people having unsafe sex with prostitutes, and yet it seems like the only group of people they want to exclude from their education program are the prostitutes themselves. If we can identify who the prostitutes are, then we can educate them. If prostitution is illegal and forced underground, we can’t provide them with info. In addition, we can’t provide information with people who use prostitutes, both because they won’t admit to committing an illegal act and because banning prostitution increases the stigma on these people. The prop has missed the point entirely when they say we will be unable to enforce regulation, because it will be in the interests of the prostitutes and brothels to abide by regulations and report those who don’t.
[Doc 427]: When the Netherlands legalized prostitution in 2000, one of its main objectives was to curtail human trafficking and the criminal prostitution enterprise. In spite of its best intentions, illegal brothels still proliferated and prostitutes continued to suffer abuses at the hands of pimps. The government is continuing to try to clean up the Red Light District by relocating its sex workers, but they fear this forced change may further put their rights and safety at risk. Similarly, Nevada’s illegal prostitution industry is estimated to be about four times as large as its legal gambling enterprise. If legalization does not protect prostitutes, then it proves

query: Is gun control justified or an infringement of our rights?

summary.claim: Arguments for Gun Control
summary.perspective:
Here is the query and documents:

Query: Is gun control justified or an infringement of our rights?

Documents:
[Doc 1767]: Shooting as a sport desensitises people to the lethal nature of all firearms, creating a gun culture that glamorises and legitimises unnecessary gun ownership. It remains the interest of a minority, who should not be allowed to block the interests of society as a whole in gun control. Compensation can be given to individual gun owners, gun clubs and the retail firearms trade, in recognition of their economic loss if a ban is implemented.
[Doc 994]: When the law meant to protect you, instead, turns you into prey, it’s understandable to want to take self-defense into your own hands. In Chicago, where there are bans on assault rifles and high-capacity magazines, and where gun shops were banned until 2012, gun control laws are not proving effective. Though the city has some of the toughest gun restrictions in place, it suffers from rising gun and gang violence. The city’s mayor, Lori Lightfoot, is working to increase public safety, but has an uphill battle. Chicago is just one example of many cities where law-abiding citizens are paying the price – with their lives – of ineffective gun control laws.
[Doc 1199]: Gun ownership exercises a fundamental individual right under the U.S. Constitution. For most upstanding citizens, owning a gun is as important to them as maintaining freedom of speech, the press, religion, among others. In fact, three quarters of gun owners believe that the right to bear arms is paramount to their freedom. No wonder gun owners take it personally when gun control laws appear to infringe on this right, thus impeding efforts to acquire firearms and protect themselves and their families. Plus, there’s the risk that certain proposed background checks may require government databases to keep gun owners’ personal information indefinitely. This could lead to future database searches unrelated to the information when it was first collected. This understandably can be perceived as an unfair invasion of privacy.
[Doc 3018]: Stopping or slowing down a customer’s internet connection is an infringement on their freedom of expression and fundamental rights. The Open Rights group have claimed these new plans are a “curtailment of people’s freedom of expression.”
[Doc 1268]: Internet access is not a fundamental right as recognized by any major human rights convention, if it can be called a right at all. After all, in a war zone few rights survive or can be upheld at all. Preventing such an outcome at the expense of the temporary curtailment of some lesser rights is entirely justified. Under current law, in most states, only the most fundamental of rights, like the right to life, prohibition against torture, slavery, and the right to a fair trial are regarded as inalienable.
[Doc 1046]: If anything, gun restrictions are aimed at making the world safer by limiting guns from getting into the wrong hands. This leads to fewer deaths. Universal background checks on private and gun show sales, an issue that survivors of the February 2018 Parkland massacre helped push legislators to prioritize, can help prevent criminals and the mentally ill from getting guns. Research asserts that federal checks could cut gun deaths by an estimated 90%. And let’s not forget about mandatory safety features. Installing safety devices on guns would minimize accidental gun deaths, especially of and by children. Think about it: We have childproof caps on medicine bottles, so why not have childproof firearms?
[Doc 1417]: Allowing teachers to carry arms in school could mean that very young children could easily become acclimatised to the idea that carrying a gun and ultimately gun usage is ok. Surely the way to prevent incidents like Columbine from happening is to teach children about the potentially destructive and fatal consequences of gun usage? For elementary/primary school-age children, it would be difficult to separate the idea that it’s ok for teachers to always carry guns but not for anyone else.
[Doc 2519]: A Nov. 2009 peer-reviewed study published in the American Journal of Public Health found that someone carrying a gun for self-defense was 4.5 times

query: Are tattoos a welcome form of self-expression or a cause of regret?

summary.claim: Tattoos can be a form of self-expression and enhance self-esteem

perspectives.text: Tattoos have the power to make you feel good, especially for people who use medical tattoos to cover scars.
A Texas Tech University study found that college-age women with four or more tattoos reported higher levels of self-esteem than anyone else in the study.
Tattoos can be used as emblems that communicate deep ideas and positive information.

summary.claim: Tattoos can be a cause of regret

perspectives.text: Many get tattoos impulsively, and that spur-of-the-moment decision is often one of the biggest predictors of tattoo regret.
A study found that nearly one in three people with a tattoo regret getting one.
Symbols, which many people choose as a tattoo, change over time, or are appropriated for different agendas of various ideologies.

query: Are Antidepressants a Good Solution?

summary.claim: Antidepressants can be a good solution for depression, as they can help restore the balance of neurotransmitters in the brain and improve symptoms.

perspectives.text: Antidepressants are small pills taken orally that seek to restore this imbalance.
Studies show that 60-70% of depressed patients who take antidepressants respond positively.
The placebo effect can also be beneficial in improving mood, regardless of the actual treatment.

summary.claim: However, antidepressants can also have negative side effects, such as gastrointestinal and sexual complications, weight gain, nausea, insomnia and/or diarrhea, and the possibility of suicidal thoughts.

perspectives.text: Fifty to 60% of antidepressant users experience significant side effects.
The possibility of suicidal thoughts is a potential side effect of almost every antidepressant.
Taking a pill for weeks without feeling a change may discourage a depressed person from continuing treatment or seeking further help.

query: Does Homework Help or Hinder Learning?

summary.claim: Homework helps
summary.perspective:
Please provide the output in the following format:
[
    {
        "claim": "Does Homework Help or Hinder Learning?",
        "positive": [
            {"text": "Homework helps students develop key skills that they’ll use throughout their lives, such as accountability, autonomy, discipline, time management, self-direction, critical thinking, and independent problem-solving.", "evidence_docs": [2663, 2300]},
            {"text": "Homework is a vital and valuable part of education. It also makes the best use of teachers, who can spend lesson time teaching rather than just supervising individual work that could be done at home.", "evidence_docs": [2300, 108]},
            {"text": "Homework allows students to go above and beyond what they do in school. Reading is the best example, students learn how to read at school, but in order to get better, they need to practise and that is best done at home, with the support of parents and at the right pace for the student.", "evidence_docs": [2300, 2664]},
            {"text": "Homework is a flashpoint for family stress, affecting children and parents equally. Parents have a number of valid reasons to dread homework as much as their kids do.", "evidence_docs": [498, 3874]},
            {"text": "Homework helps students learn to meet deadlines, to work independently and create their own study methods, and yes, how to approach assignments they might not be particularly interested in.", "evidence_docs": [566, 322]},
            {"text": "Students who engage in self-regulatory processes while completing homework, such as goal-setting, time management, and remaining focused, are generally more motivated and are higher achievers than those who do not use these processes.", "evidence_docs": [2663, 2664]},
            {"text": "Homework is a vital part of education. There are only a few hours in each school day – not enough time to cover properly all the subjects children need to study.", "evidence_docs": [2300, 74]}
        ],
        "negative": [
            {"text": "Homework can damage family relationships as it means parents have to try and make their children do their homework.", "evidence_docs": [2269, 268]},
            {"text": "Excessive homework can lead to over burden on the mind of the child, and less time for physical development.", "evidence_docs": [3873, 3874]},
            {"text": "Homework can exacerbate achievement gaps between rich and poor students, rendering homework not only counterproductive, but a barrier to equality.", "evidence_docs": [322, 2664]},
            {"text": "Homework can be stressful, boring and tiring, and it is simply much harder to make homework engaging and interesting as it is often done on our own.", "evidence_docs": [2271]},
            {"text": "The burden of homework plays a large part in the stress of elementary school kids, with more than a decade ago a 2007 study by Metlife already reported that 28% of students in grades 3-6 were ‘often’ or ‘very often’ stressed out by homework and, since then, stress among children has only grown.", "evidence_docs": [532]},
            {"text": "Homework can cause headaches and stomach problems, and some children experience sleep deprivation by staying up too late to finish their homework.", "evidence_docs": [532, 3874]},
            {"text": "A Duke University review of 25 years’ worth of studies on homework found a positive statistical correlation between homework and higher achievement, especially at the secondary-school level.", "evidence_docs": [222]},
            {"text": "Studies done on this come to different conclusions so teachers should only set homework when they are sure it is needed.", "evidence_docs": [2271, 108]},
            {"text": "Homework is a waste of time and does not help students learn anything new.", "evidence_docs": [3874, 3873]}

query: Sigmund Freud: A timeless genius or overrated?

summary.claim: Sigmund Freud: A timeless genius or overrated?

perspectives.text: Freud's groundbreaking work in developing psychoanalysis laid the foundation for modern psychology.

Freud's exploration into the complexities of motivation, human sexuality, and the creative process inspired many philosophers, scholars, and artists.
Freud's theories were developed in the late 19th and early 20th centuries, and they were influenced by the cultural and societal norms of his time.
Freud's ideas, particularly those related to sexuality, psychosexual stages of development, and gender, are outdated and reflect the biases of his era.
Freud's theories have been criticized for being simplistic, and his focus on sexual explanations for psychological incidents has been seen as limited.

Freud's refusal to treat people unless they could pay him limited his exposure to issues and further limited his theories' applicability.

Freud's legacy is complex and multifaceted, and his impact on modern psychology cannot be overstated.

summary.claim: Sigmund Freud: A timeless genius or overrated?

Please provide the JSON output based on the provided documents. 

Note: The document IDs (doc_1, doc_2,...) are placeholders and should be replaced with the actual IDs of the documents that support each perspective. 

Here is the query: Should We Distribute Condoms in High Schools?

Here are the documents:
[Doc 145]: In high schools that teach students about both abstinence and contraception use, these programs are sending mixed messages to students. If a school wants its students not to have sex, it shouldn’t provide them with condoms to use during intercourse. Furthermore, making condoms available in schools might send the erroneous message to students that their teachers and parents are expecting them to engage in sexual activity.
[Doc 765]: Condom distribution in high schools gives students a false sense of security when having sex. This is because most teenagers lack experience with condom implementation and use, causing the condoms to be extremely ineffective. When used perfectly every single time during sex, condoms are 98% effective at preventing pregnancy. But people, especially teenagers, aren’t perfect, so, typically, condoms may only about 85% effective. Not to mention the fact that vulnerable teenage girls still have less control over condom use.
[Doc 1160]: By providing condoms to students, high schools are taking away the due right of parents to decide whether their own teenage children should have access to contraception. To begin with, many parents don’t think that their adolescent children are emotionally or physically ready yet for sex. So, having schools introduce condom use to their teenagers pressures both the parents and teens into having conversations about sex that may feel premature. It may also interfere with a family’s values or religious beliefs. For instance, the Catholic Church and other conservative faiths oppose various forms of contraception. Parents who support the cause can provide condoms to their teenagers without having schools infringe on other families’ timelines of talking about sex and/or religious freedoms.
[Doc 1029]: As teenagers are beginning to discover their sexual identities, providing condoms in high schools can help them establish the concept of safe sex as the norm and gives them the mandate to be responsible. Research shows that 60% of high schoolers have had sex by the time they graduate. Therefore, introducing the idea of condom use into their conscience at such a formative age may help teens view contraception as second nature as opposed to something that either gender will have to continually negotiate with future partners. Also worth noting, with the Supreme Court’s overturn of Roe V. Wade, access to abortion is getting more limited across the US, which only emphasizes the need for more access to condoms.
[Doc 3536]: On the disparity between private and state schools, the correct way to improve the education for children in state schools is to spend more money on state schools, devote more time, energy and enthusiasm to them. Preventing a minority from having a certain type of education is not the way to help improve the majority’s education. By and large, the complaint is that private schools are doing well and providing a good education, whilst state schools lag behind. It is in all our interests to set the standard of education as high as we can – you do this by raising state schools to the supposed standard of private schools, not by depriving children of a private education.
[Doc 2278]: State schools will, like the private schools, have to offer a high quality service in order that parents do not take their children elsewhere. This incentivises in particular high level management, who, if the school fails, will be out of a job with a blot on their record.
[Doc 671]: Among U.S. high school students surveyed by the CDC in 2021, 30% were sexually active. Of these, 48% of them didn’t use a condom during their last sexual encounter. The same study also showed that half of the 20 million new STDs reported in the United States each year are among 15- to 24-year-olds, and that people aged 13-24 accounted for an estimated 20% of all new HIV diagnoses in 2018. These numbers emphasize the importance of condom distribution in high schools for sexually active

query: The Perspective on Surrogacy

summary.claim: Three reasons in favor of surrogacy
summary.perspective:
Here is the list of documents:
[Doc 708]: Surrogacy is a paid “job” that women perform, often while attempting to remain emotionally detached from the “product of their work.” This would be fine in some work environments, but in the case of surrogacy, alienated labor that culminates in physical reproductive labor can be psychologically and physically harmful for the surrogate mother. It can also turn the entire surrogacy process into a physical act lacking in emotional attachment This is because surrogates might be compelled to sell their bodies and their function for money, while attempting to distance themselves from the significance of their acts and shield themselves from potential postpartum heartbreak.
[Doc 520]: Today, approximately 11% of American women struggle with infertility. For people unable to conceive due to infertility or medical conditions, surrogacy can be one of the only ways in which they finally create a family. Surrogacy can help single men and women and LGBT couples become parents, enabling at least one parent to be biologically linked to their child. Plus, having kids and forming a family has been positively linked with increased parental happiness, productivity and longevity, for all family members. Some research even suggests that parents are happier than non-parents later in life, once their children move out. Basically, surrogacy can create the foundation for a happier, more fulfilled life.
[Doc 430]: Surrogacy can be problematic in instances where it is used by wealthier people to dominate and degrade women from lower socio-economic backgrounds, particularly in third-world countries. The woman’s unique childbearing capabilities are recognized and used to bring money in. The issue of consent is at times unclear. Countries like India offer surrogacy services to Western countries at a fraction of the cost, which can be seen as exploiting women as baby-making machines for a pittance. The low price tag can be tempting to couples and individuals of higher economic means who are desperate to expand their families, driving them to enter into surrogacy agreements with third-world women, despite the way these contracts may affect these surrogates. In Ukraine, for example, couples may pay anywhere between $30K-$50K for the process while the surrogate mothers reportedly receive only a small fraction of this sum.
[Doc 379]: To better understand surrogacy, we must look at the alternatives available to people hoping to become parents. One alternative is adoption. Despite there being many children around the world in desperate need of homes, it can take years for a single child to be adopted. Then, adoptive parents must get to know a child who is already born and who biologically belongs to someone else. It may also be challenging to find out a comprehensive health history of the adopted child, which may cause complications later in life for everyone involved. Clearly, adoption is not easy. While the surrogacy process can also be challenging, especially when the surrogate mother is in a different country where war can break out, surrogacy does ensure that intended parents can be involved in their child’s life from the get-go. Intended parents are updated on the surrogate’s pregnancy, and often can attend scans and be present when the baby, often theirs biologically, is born.
[Doc 1075]: In countries that allow and support commercial surrogacy, surrogate mothers are fairly compensated for their time and the medical risk involved. These women are instructed about the process, what medical procedures are required and how they must conduct themselves throughout the gestational period. Contracts are signed to protect the surrogate and intended parents to ensure that all parties get what they want. For the intended parents, this means a baby. For the regulated surrogate – a base compensation of around $25,000 can be expected, though it can be more and the absolving of her responsibility towards the child and its intended parents following childbirth. From an equality perspective, surrogate mothers are well informed and conscious of their choice. The act of surrogacy can therefore be viewed as an educated and informed economic opportunity.
[Doc 503]: When surrogacy is allowed, babies become commodities for trade, often between wealthy Westerners and impoverished families in developing countries. This international trade

query: Does Nicki Minaj Empower or Objectify women?

summary.claim: Nicki Minaj Empowers Women

perspectives.text: Nicki Minaj's performances exemplify female empowerment. She uses her sexuality to make money, and she clearly enjoys her own sexuality. Making it acceptable for women to shed their inhibitions and enjoy men's bodies is a positive message.

Nicki Minaj's performances exemplify female empowerment. She uses her sexuality to make money, and she clearly enjoys her own sexuality. Making it acceptable for women to shed their inhibitions and enjoy men's bodies is a positive message.

summary.claim: Nicki Minaj Objectifies Women

perspectives.text: The way Nicki Minaj unashamedly displays her body, in general and in her performances, gives off an overly sexualized view of women. Whether intentional or not, Minaj enforces sexist stereotypes suggesting that a woman's value is directly proportional to how she looks and how men judge and assess her attractiveness.

Minaj uses her body for sexual marketing, which is far different from using her body to promote sex-positive feminism. Take, for example, her Anaconda album cover, which blatantly uses her body and the idea of sex to sell her music and brand.

Minaj has made a name for herself because of her many and long-standing celebrity feuds – most of which have involved only women. These tendencies to publicly pit women against each other, criticize their art, or refer to them as “b*tches” shows a lack of respect and grace for other women in the industry.

query: Messi or Ronaldo – who is truly the best?

summary.claim: Messi is the better player

perspectives.text: Messi has an advantage over Ronaldo: Messi has won more titles mostly because he plays for a better team, not because he is a better player than Ronaldo.
Both Messi and Ronaldo have impressive stats, but a closer look at them proves Messi makes better decisions and, more importantly, brings greater value to his team.

Messi is a greater natural talent. He is a virtuoso, a magician. His dribbling is considered to be the best the game has ever seen, and he passes and shoots the ball with the precision of a brain surgeon.
Messi is like Tim Duncan of the Spurs, while Ronaldo is like LeBron James in Cleveland.
Messi makes better decisions. Using a complex algorithm, a company called GoodCall values a player’s decision-making and Efficiency Per Match (EPM).

Messi has the added value of an unforgettable team, Neymar Jr., Luis Suarez, two of the best forwards of the century, and with Xavi Hernandez and Andrés Iniesta, two of the most dominating center-midfielders of our era.
Messi has outscored Ronaldo in the last minutes of the game, otherwise known as injury-time goals.
Messi is a true leader, he brings his team together.

summary.claim: Ronaldo is the better player

perspectives.text: Ronaldo’s international career puts him on a higher level than Messi. In fact, before the 2022 World Cup, Messi never won an international trophy.
Ronaldo has better international goalscoring stats in competitive international games than Messi (102 goals compared to Messi’s 54),
Ronaldo is the higher paid football player of the two, which proves his higher worth.
Ronaldo is a machine. He is an explosive player, with abnormal physical abilities and a huge amount of talent.
Ronaldo doesn’t possess Messi’s magic.
Ronaldo is 6’’1 of pure Portuguese muscle. This means he’s very hard to push off the ball.
Ronaldo’s combination of dizzying pace, great dribbling and powerful shooting with either foot terrorizes defenses.
Ronaldo is doing it at the same level even in his late-30s.
Ronaldo is the ideal model for the next generation of players.

query: Do Professional Athletes Deserve Their Inflated Salaries?

summary.claim: Professional athletes deserve their inflated salaries because they put their bodies at risk and make significant sacrifices.

perspectives.text: Professional athletes sacrifice important aspects of their lives, especially their health and family. For instance, during each season of any professional sport, there are away games that keep players from their families. More significant, though, is that players put their bodies in danger daily. query: The Perspective on Bill Clinton

summary.claim: Bill Clinton created more jobs than any president in US history

perspectives.text: Clinton created more jobs than any president in US history. In 1992, the year before he took office, unemployment was at 7.5%. His policies reduced it to 4% by the time he left the White House.
However, his policies also led to a significant increase in the national debt, which could be seen as a negative consequence.

summary.claim: Bill Clinton hugely undercut the American welfare system

perspectives.text: Clinton reduced the amount of American families that received welfare from 4 million to 1.6 million, and his policies contributed to benefits falling by 32.5%.
However, this reduction in welfare benefits did not necessarily lead to a decrease in poverty, and some argue that the policies had unintended consequences.

query: Edward Snowden – Hero or Traitor?

summary.claim: Edward Snowden acted responsibly when he revealed that the NSA's surveillance program was unconstitutional.

perspectives.text: Snowden acted responsibly when he revealed that the NSA's surveillance program was unconstitutional. He was careful in not leaking any details about the algorithms that the NSA used in its operations. Nor did the leaks reveal the identities of the groups or individuals that the agency had targeted or the US agents involved.
Snowden's decision to share this information consequently prompted a global debate over surveillance techniques and protecting citizens' privacy.
The leaked data also didn’t contain any details of US military plans or conversations between US or foreign officials.

summary.claim: Edward Snowden is a traitor.

perspectives.text: He risked his own freedom to bring information into the public domain about the US government endangering its citizens’ civil liberties.
Former US Attorney General Eric Holder, who believes Snowden is a traitor, admitted that he “performed a public service.”
The majority of the information that he shared is about the U.S. spying on foreign nations and not its domestic operations.

query: Should we invest in Bitcoin or stay away from it?

summary.claim: Doomed to fail, bit by bit
summary.perspective:
Here is the query: Should we invest in Bitcoin or stay away from it?
Here are the documents:
[Doc 1064]: Attempts to regulate Bitcoin have been underway for a while. For example, the IRS treats Bitcoin as property and taxes it as such. Meanwhile, Bitcoin is both decentralized – meaning it has no central role of management or authority – and unstable. Some may see its decentralization as a good thing, but this opened it up for black market trading in the past. In fact, in 2016, over 10% of Bitcoin transactions happened on The Silk Road, a hidden online service (which is now defunct ) that allowed for trading drugs, illegal substances, and other illicit activities. In 2020, $1 billion in bitcoin was said to be linked to criminal activity.
[Doc 456]: As of now, Bitcoin has the potential to become an environmental disaster. While it may seem like it saves resources, the Bitcoin Energy Consumption Tracker currently shows that Bitcoin consumes 146.86 Terawatt hours per year, and that number is only going up. To put that in perspective, that’s comparable to the annual power consumption of Ukraine or the annual carbon footprint of Romania, and one Bitcoin transaction could cost as much water as a backyard swimming pool. Currently, the amount of energy it takes to “mine” (i.e., create) and use Bitcoin is unsustainable in the long term.
[Doc 655]: Bitcoin is catching on, regardless of any personal aversion to it. It is already considered as one of the world’s top currencies and is becoming more and more mainstream; Elon Musk’s Tesla invested $1.5 billion in Bitcoin in 2021 while certain colleges even accept it as payment. In fact, there are reports that JPMorgan, among others on Wall Street, are accepting Bitcoin as an asset class. Even the U.S. Federal Reserve is reportedly creating a bank-to-bank digital currency, proving just how relevant Bitcoin already is to the future of currency.
[Doc 719]: Many see the overall rise in Bitcoin prices as a bubble, due to its volatility. In finance terms, a “bubble” is when the price of an asset far surpasses its fundamental value, implying that its preliminary spike in value will eventually crash and burn. For example, in 2008, the U.S. housing bubble popped, leading to an economic crisis, which became the Great Recession. In this vein, whenever Bitcoin prices drop, experts warn that they will only continue to fall, especially in the long run, even after temporary recoveries. Also, Bitcoin takes money and power away from institutions that are used to being in charge – namely, banks and governments. It’s reasonable to assume that given all the revenues they stand to lose, they won’t take this lying down; they have all the resources in the world at their disposable to combat the success of virtual currency.
[Doc 148]: Bitcoin has allowed people to put their trust in technology instead of third-party mediators like banks and civil-law notaries. This is because it relies on blockchain technology, which is a complex mathematical model that instantly creates a virtual chain of recorded transactions when Bitcoin is transferred from one place to another. These transactions are easily verifiable, and will eliminate the possibility of human error, steep transaction fees, and long wait times when transferring money. In other words, Bitcoin makes the whole process of using money more efficient by cutting out the middlemen who have had to oversee every transaction that takes place thus far. This is why mainstream payment firms like PayPal are not only investing in it but offering it as an option to their platform.
[Doc 621]: Illustrious investor Warren Buffet has long warned people to “never invest in a business you cannot understand.” He has advised to only invest in companies that you already know about, which is difficult to do with small-change apps that often invest in companies of their choosing. Depending on apps to do your work for you may be advantageous in the beginning but will hinder you from learning the craft of investing long term and learning how to make real money by investing independently. When the time comes for you to invest more than just your spare change

query: Is Real Estate the Best Investment?

summary.claim: Real estate can be a good investment due to its ability to appreciate in value over time and provide a tangible asset.

perspectives.text: Real estate is a tangible asset that can be used as collateral for loans and can provide a sense of security and stability.
The ability of real estate to appreciate in value over time makes it a good investment opportunity for those looking to build wealth.

summary.claim: Real estate may not be the best investment option due to its high maintenance costs, limited liquidity, and potential for market fluctuations.

perspectives.text: Real estate investments can be subject to high maintenance costs, including property taxes, insurance, and repairs.
The limited liquidity of real estate investments can make it difficult to access funds quickly if needed.
Real estate investments are subject to market fluctuations, which can result in losses if the market declines.

query: Should we Raise the Minimum Wage?

summary.claim: Raising the minimum wage would lift 4.5 million Americans out of poverty.

perspectives.text: The 20 richest Americans own as much wealth as the bottom half of the country combined.
Income inequality has been shown to fuel social tension so reducing it is in everyone’s best interest.
A plan to raise the minimum wage to $12/h by 2020 would reduce income inequality.
The US lags far behind other developed countries in terms of income inequality.

summary.claim: Raising the minimum wage would lead to reduced employment, increased thefts, drug sales, and violent crime.

perspectives.text: According to a 2013 study by Boston College economists, increasing the minimum wage leads to reduced employment.
Their results indicate that crime will increase by 1.9 percentage points among 14-30 year-olds as the minimum wage increases.
Researchers found that between 1977 and 2012 increases in the minimum wage resulted in no significant change in the rates of violent crime or property crime.

query: Is Home Ownership Still Worthwhile?

summary.claim: Home ownership can be a powerful financial tool for individuals.

perspectives.text: Home equity can be used to finance anticipated expenses like college tuition and vacations at significantly lower interest rates than those offered on student or personal loans.
Homeownership can provide monthly dividends for those who decide to turn their homes into rentals.
Home equity loans and lines of credit can help to turn a fixed asset into a liquid one.

summary.claim: Home ownership may not be the best option for everyone, particularly those who value their personal space and work-life balance.

perspectives.text: Working from home can be a double-edged sword, as it can make it harder to achieve a healthy work-life balance and, therefore, is not suitable to all personality types.
For a workaholic, working from home is roughly equivalent to conducting an AA meeting in a distillery.
Telecommuters who are unable to snap out of 'personal mode' when working from home may struggle to maintain productivity.

query: Battle of the consoles : Xbox vs. PlayStation

summary.claim: Xbox offers more value for money than PlayStation

perspectives.text: Xbox allows for backwards compatibility, is cheaper to begin with, and comes with an Ultra HD Blu-Ray player.
Xbox also allows for easy switching between computer, TV, and games, and has a HDMI input for home cable connection.
Xbox Live offers a more reliable online experience with heightened reliability and speed.

summary.claim: PlayStation has a clearer image on screen and more horsepower than Xbox

perspectives.text: PlayStation has 50% more GPU compute units, allowing for greater parallel processing power.
PlayStation has a sharper 1920 x 1080 resolution compared to Xbox's 1600 x 900.
PlayStation's hardware environment is better controlled, making it easier for game developers to design games.

query: Should we Fight or Embrace Illegal Downloads?

summary.claim: There are too many cheap alternatives to illegal downloading to continue perpetuating the activity.

File-sharers are directly responsible for damaging the music industry.

summary.claim: It is impossible to overstate the power that the threat of prosecution has to stay the hand of anyone, including a politician, from transgressing the laws of the state.

We need more aggressive prosecution of politicians.

query: The Perspective on Elon Musk

summary.claim: Musk is a visionary and has had a positive impact on the world

perspectives.text: Musk is a visionary, and his dreams alone have had a positive global impact.
His most recent partnership with T-Mobile will make cellphone service available almost everywhere in the US, even remote corners.
His car company Tesla has steered the automotive industry towards a new era with semi-autonomous vehicles and electric cars, globally reducing vehicle emissions.
His aim to sell 20 million electric vehicles in 2030 alone will significantly reduce carbon emissions.

summary.claim: Musk is a flawed individual with a tendency to prioritize his own interests over the well-being of others

perspectives.text: Musk has been accused of being arrogant and dismissive of the dangers of COVID-19, as well as being reckless with the lives of his employees.
He has been known to prioritize his own interests over the well-being of others, such as when he re-opened his Tesla plant despite two employees testing positive for COVID-19.
He has also been accused of playing with the lives of his employees by pushing them to work long hours and pull all-nighters.
His actions have resulted in plummeting Twitter stock prices and morale.

query: Does Wall Street embody flawed ethics or economic success?

summary.claim: Wall Street embodies economic success

perspectives.text: Wall Street employees are making high salaries and bonuses, and the firm has a high level of employee satisfaction.
Wall Street provides liquidity to the stock market, allowing companies to raise capital and invest in vital industries.
Wall Street has created many jobs in vital industries like technology.
Wall Street has a significant impact on the economy, providing opportunities for investment and economic growth.

summary.claim: Wall Street embodies flawed ethics

perspectives.text: Wall Street traders have inside information that gives them an unfair advantage over other investors.
Wall Street bonuses are high, but the financial deck is stacked in Wall Street's favor, with traders making more than average Americans.
Wall Street firms have spent millions of dollars on lobbying, which can influence government policy to favor their interests.
Wall Street's focus on profit can lead to exploitation of vulnerable individuals, such as low-income households.

query: Will Nuclear Power advance or ruin humanity?

summary.claim: Nuclear power can advance humanity by reducing carbon emissions and providing energy

perspectives.text: Nuclear energy has a critical role to play in curbing the carbon emissions that accelerate global warming and climate change.
NASA predicts that broadening the use of nuclear energy can save between 4 million and 7 million lives by 2050.
France and Japan, the world’s biggest nuclear energy consumers, also have the world’s lowest rate of CO2 emissions.

summary.claim: Nuclear power can ruin humanity by creating a risk of nuclear accidents and proliferation

perspectives.text: An accident with nuclear weapons could set off warning systems and a chain reaction that would be disastrous.
Nations will never entirely give up their nuclear weapons, and more countries want to proliferate, not fewer.
The raw materials and technology required to generate nuclear energy can be manipulated to produce weapons of mass destruction.

query: Startups: Is it better to be first or second to the market?

summary.claim: Being the first to the market has its advantages.

perspectives.text: The first mover has a failure rate of 47% as opposed to the 8% failure rate of the first follower.
By being the first brand to sell a product, if done right, you can make your brand name almost synonymous with the type of product.
The first mover has a huge advantage in building a lasting relationship with their customers.
The first mover can make their brand name almost synonymous with the type of product.

summary.claim: Being the second to the market can also have its advantages.

perspectives.text: The first follower can see that there exists market demand for their product.
The first follower can learn from the mistakes previously made by others in the field.
The first follower can benefit from the improvements made by the first mover.
The first follower can benefit from the data that was already available to the first mover.

query: Is Amazon Good or Bad for the Shopping Industry?
THE PERSPECTIVE ON DIGITAL MARKETING

summary.claim: Digital marketing has opened up new opportunities for small and medium-sized businesses.

perspectives.text: Digital marketing enhances the voice and precision of any interested individual for any budget and with minimal know-how.
Digital marketing provides a clear understanding of what works and what needs fixing, allowing businesses to make data-driven decisions.

summary.claim: Digital marketing has led to the homogenization of marketing strategies and the loss of unique perspectives.

perspectives.text: The analytical approach has created a reality where most marketers perform the same actions, on relatively few platforms.
This lack of diversity in marketing strategies can lead to a lack of creativity and innovation.

query: The Perspective on Google: is it too powerful?

summary.claim: Google brings new meaning to globalization

perspectives.text: Google brings new meaning to globalization. Thanks to the last decade of the company’s innovation and low-cost mobile broadband, developing countries like India, among many others, have free access to information, to which much of the rest of the world is already privy. With Google Search operating in over 135 different languages and Google Translate operating in 108 languages, the company’s ability to provide accurate translations to so many international viewers means that every web page is territory to be charted equally by anyone around the globe. Also, because the company is privately owned, the speed at which it can impact developing nations is much faster than that of governments with complicated interests to protect. Plus, Google’s annual Economic Impact reports assert that its search and advertising tools helped drive $385 billion in US economic activity in 2019. It’s ads and searches directly led to clicks for 16 million American businesses alone that same year.
Google has immense access to research on every subject in any field, allowing them to advance science in a way no other company can.

summary.claim: Google is too powerful

perspectives.text: Google has been accused of using its wealth to influence all levels of policymakers. This accusation seems to carry weight; the company has funded 330 papers on public policy alone since 2005. Additionally, in trying to defend themselves against claims that Google tampered with a 2012 FTC investigation, the company admitted in 2015 to having influence in Washington across a number of political domains.

Google’s search engine market share is 90%. The US government seems to think that Google is an illegal monopoly and is consequently suing the tech giant to break it up and halt alleged antitrust abuses.
Google’s APIs for Android has allowed people to develop their own apps and utilize them to grow revenue. However, this has led to a lack of competition and innovation in the market.

Google’s ability to provide accurate translations to so many international viewers means that every web page is territory to be charted equally by anyone around the globe. This has led to a lack of local businesses and innovation in the market.
